data.title: Excerpts from Poseidonâ€™s Boat Blog
data.meta_description: Lillian Stone and Evan Allgood humorously imagine what the mighty sea god Poseidon might write on his boat-review blog.
data.text:
FOR EONS, MEN HAVE TRAVERSED MY ROILING WATERS IN THEIR PUNY VESSELS. Iâ€™m sorryâ€”the caps lock was on.

For eons, men have traversed my roiling waters in their puny vessels. Although Iâ€™m both feared and revered as the Lord of the Sea (and also of earthquakes, storms, and, of course, horses), no one ever stops to ask, â€œHmm, I wonder what Poseidon has to say about all these little boats attempting to cross His mighty domain?â€

Well, Iâ€™ve got some opinionsâ€”opinions to be expressed here, in Poseidonâ€™s Waterlogged Boat Blog, which I (Poseidon) will update regularly. Thanks for reading, but donâ€™t correct my grammar, lest I strike ye down in a whirling rage with briny bilge and orca innards!

Speedboat

This nomenclature would be like me, Poseidon, calling myself a â€œpowerman.â€ True power is having a 2006 Josh Lucas film named after you.

Rating: ğŸ”± [one out of five tridents]

Jet Ski

The perfect boat . . . for gliding away from your responsibilities, â€‹Triton.â€‹ (My son Triton still lives at home.) Iâ€™m sorryâ€”I promised myself that I wouldnâ€™t let the boat blog become a place where I just vent about Triton. This is the last time Iâ€™ll mention him. From here on out, itâ€™s strictly boats.

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”±

Submarine

These crafts are skulking cowards, not unlike my son Triton. Always slinking about in Davy Jonesâ€™s Locker (my basement). I let him live rent-free in my golden underwater palace, and he drags his heels across the oceanâ€™s depths, listening to self-care audiobooks. I donâ€™t care what anyone saysâ€”â€œthe doldrumsâ€ is not a medical condition.

Rating: ğŸ”±

Sea-Doo 2020 Personal Watercraft

Saw this snappy vehicle sailing through the waters just the other day. Thought to myself, What brung ye here, snappy thing? Decided that I wanted to keep it for myself, so I tossed its wailing captain into a watery grave, where the harpies got him.

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”±

Yacht

For ten long years, I, the Dread Emperor, made Odysseusâ€™ life hell and kept him from his family, all because he wouldnâ€™t let my large son Polyphemus eat him. Polyphemus, now thereâ€™s a son! So large, so hungry, with his own cave and everything. Anyway, I find yachts a bit showy.

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”±

Steamboat

I burned my trident-gripping hand on one of theseâ€”not on the boat itself, but on the steam. No one told me about the hot steam! These are the things you donâ€™t learn when you spend your childhood among a flock of lambs, hidden from your son-hungry father. I would have LOVED to have cushy accommodations in a golden underwater palace and a famous-writer father with a well-trafficked boat blog on the verge of corporate sponsorship.

Rating: ğŸ”±

Barge

Flat-bottomed, plankton-encrusted, and self-propelled. One of those adjectives does not describe my son Triton. Can you guess which one?

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”±

Carnival Ocean Liner

For a long time, I thought that this was a garish whale. I was, like, O.K., that whale is floating atop the brine? Which I did not sanction? Then I realized that it wasnâ€™t a whale, but a large boat featuring a massive water slide. Lo, I intend to lop off that water slide via a brutal norâ€™easter wind. Itâ€™ll slice through the air with the precision of a Joeâ€™s Crab Shack sous-chef, striking down the passengers, mid-revelry. I dare any of my readers to conjure a crueler punishment for hubristic passengers of the god-defying, water-slided mega-cruise! FOR TEN PER CENT OFF AT JOEâ€™S CRAB SHACK, USE PROMO CODE WHYTRITON.

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”±

Lifeboat

Adorable.

Rating: ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”± ğŸ”±
